title: Erris Head
text:
Erris Head (<a href="Irish%20language">Irish</a>: "Ceann Iorrais") is a <a href="headland">promontory</a> at the northernmost tip of the <a href="Mullet%20Peninsula">Mullet Peninsula</a>, located in the barony of <a href="Erris">Erris</a> in northwest <a href="County%20Mayo">County Mayo</a>, <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>. It is a well known and recognised landmark used by mariners and weather forecasters, and is also a scenic viewpoint, with an unobstructed view of the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and steep rocky cliffs. It is not served by any road and can only be reached by crossing a number of fields.
Special Area of Conservation.
Erris Head has been designated a <a href="Special%20Area%20of%20Conservation">Special Area of Conservation</a> (SAC) under the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>'s Habitats Directive.
This dry heath supports <a href="Juniperus%20communis">juniper</a>, <a href="Arctostaphylos%20uva-ursi">bearberry</a>, <a href="Empetrum%20nigrum">crowberry</a> and <a href="Calluna">heather</a>. There are wet flushes and areas of wet heath, and here grow <a href="Juncus%20subnodulosus">blunt-flowered rush</a>, three species of <a href="Drosera">sundew</a> and the rare <a href="Epipactis%20palustris">marsh heleborine orchid</a>.
Seabirds nest on the cliffs, with <a href="fulmar">fulmar</a>s and <a href="great%20black-backed%20gull">great black-backed gull</a>s being most numerous, and <a href="peregrine%20falcon">peregrine falcon</a>s and <a href="chough">chough</a>s also breed here. In winter, <a href="Barnacle%20goose">barnacle geese</a> feed on the grasslands above the cliff. <a href="Mountain%20hare">Irish hares</a> and <a href="common%20frog">common frog</a>s occur on the headland, and <a href="grey%20seal">grey seal</a>s can often be seen at the foot of the cliffs.
